title: Remembering Elizabeth Kelly: A Legacy in Television
summary: Elizabeth Kelly, a veteran actress renowned for her role as Nellie Ellis in the BBC soap opera EastEnders, passed away at the age of 104 in Scarborough on December 31. Her agent, Scott Marshall Partners, announced her peaceful death and highlighted her illustrious 40-year career in television. Kelly began acting in the late 1960s and gained early recognition for her role as Edie Burgess in Coronation Street in 1971. She later appeared in various drama series such as The Bill and Where the Heart Is. In 1993, she joined EastEnders as the sharp-tongued Nellie Ellis, a character she portrayed until 1998, with a final appearance in 2000. The BBC issued a statement praising her warmth and kindness, expressing sadness at her passing. This article serves as an obituary, detailing her professional journey and the impact she had on the entertainment industry, while also noting unrelated content about other EastEnders actors that may distract from the main focus.

background_read: Elizabeth Kelly was a British actress born in Newcastle who embarked on her acting career in the late 1960s. She became a familiar face on British television, particularly in soap operas, which are serialized dramas focusing on everyday life and relationships. Her role as Nellie Ellis in EastEnders, a long-running BBC soap set in London, cemented her place in popular culture. EastEnders is known for its dramatic storylines and has been a staple of British TV since 1985. Kelly's career spanned multiple decades, reflecting changes in the television industry and audience preferences. This article provides context on her contributions to entertainment, while also highlighting the broader impact of soap operas in shaping public discourse and nostalgia.
